posts.content:
now my vans mechanically sound, for now at least, im going to spend a bit of time sorting out an interior, the plan is to have two bench seats with a table in the centre which will slide down to bridge the benches and form a bed
right starting off with a nice clean blank canvas,
many hours with a wire mop, rust treatment and several coats of hammerite



was going to go down the route of coffee bean bag door cards, having seen a few of them about recently i decided to try and make something a little bit different. Started off getting a roll of hessian, cutting it to fit some ply card then got the missus to do some screen prints onto them






rear end covered with flashing tape to deaden a bit of sound, hopefully tomorrow i will be getting some plywood and vinyl down, not sure wether to glue or screw the flooring down...

spent the last couple of days building some bench seat frames



still got a bit more to do to make a bit more structural! had an idea of having the benches style similar to wooden cargo shipping containers, decided to go looking for knackered pallets for the wooden slats!
found this one down the garden, been proping up the fence for the past couple of years!



a few hours with a belt sander later and i started to find some nice clean dry wood underneath





anyone got any ideas as to the best way to keep the benches in place? i was going to drill a couple of holes in the floor and bolt them in, dont really fancy putting holes in a floor ive spent so long welding back up aha

Nice work there fella I like the theme....tres cool

When I did mine I laid a plywood floor and simply used "L" brackets screwed into the frames and then the floor. Certainly no holes in the metal cargo floor itself

viewtopic.php?f=8&t=51928&hilit=my+13+window&start=45

This takes you to where I laid the floor and then you can see the rest from there.

Hope it helps.

Adam

Like Adam says, I think laying a plywood floor is the only way of fitting the benches without drilling holes.

You can just bond the ply to the floor.
Of course you could make slats like the floor on a trekker
Cheers,
Dom.

Spent a fair while preping the pallet wood, went over it lightly with some wood oil as i want it as light as possible, im undecided whether to have the entire bench made of the slats of whether to use ply with some slats around the edge as the benches are very heavy with all this thick timber, i think i will cut out some ply to fit and see which i prefer

how about using 1/4 ply covered in hessian for the bench sides.
Pallet wood is heavy!
Cheers,
Dom.
Love the screen prints mate, how did you do them? Will the wife do a 'how to'?

hessian benches...not a bad idea that. im all out so may be ordering a bit more. googled shipping crate boxes and got alot of images with ply boxes with a timber frame, had a go to see how it looks. much prefer it to pallet wood all over





the missis did the screen prints while she still had access to her university studio as she has just finished doing fine art. from what i remember as to 'how to' i think you have to rent a studio but you can use any image as long as it can be photocopied...ill have a word and get her to do a step by step guide
ive told her to start making some but from what she says renting the equipment is quite expensive
Looking cool, lovin the traditional sailor style tattoo prints.

been lagging a bit on the interior due to starter issues but now all thats been resolved im back on it!
spent a bit of time last week doing the second bench, so here we are









just need to make up some sort of table, i was going to have a full width table that would drop down to bridge the benches and form a bed, change of plans now as i tried a quick mock up and had no space whatsoever! so might make half a table with a hinge underneath...

Looking good.
I take it you've seen the Sailor Jerry Ratrod?

Orb

ive not actually seen that Orb, such a bad ass hot rod tho
loving the sailor jerry ragtop, given me an idea for a table too might have to step up my game after seeing that!

came to a point a couple of months ago where the interior is comfortable and useable so just been enjoying it, just come back from a 600 mile 1 week adventure down south and im happy the interior hasnt fallen to bits aha, so heres what its looking like atm, decided not to have such a large table as it would of taken up too much space, so put something that resembles a shelf up also got a couple of lenghs of wood which i use to form the bed that can be easily stored.
no carpentry masterpiece but fun and useable
